awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Investigation of Spin Evolution in Magnetic Ultracold Neutron Bottles Used to Measure the Free Neutron Lifetime
awd_abstract_narration:
An isolated neutron lives for about fifteen minutes before disintegrating into three lighter particles. This fundamental process plays a significant role in cosmology, and its study complements current efforts to discover new physics. Two laboratory techniques exist to determine the lifetime of a neutron with high precision, but they disagree significantly in their reported values. This discrepancy must be addressed in order to realize the potential of these techniques to help probe new physics. The research conducted with this award directly supports that effort by examining the behavior of very low energy (or "ultracold") neutrons which are magnetically confined in order to determine the neutron lifetime. The research involves a broad set of ideas and skills appropriate for undergraduate involvement and will be used to form the kernel for an interdisciplinary undergraduate research training, mentoring, and outreach program at Tennessee Technological University. 

Research activities will be carried out in conjunction with the UCNtau collaboration, which has constructed a magneto-gravitational ultracold neutron trap with a long intrinsic neutron storage time and demonstrated a detection strategy capable of making multiple high-precision measurements in a single accelerator cycle at the Los Alamos National Laboratory ultracold neutron source. Losses due to spin evolution in this trap will be empirically characterized by developing a high-fidelity spin-tracking Monte Carlo simulation of the experiment which, when combined with measurements of the mean trap lifetime as a function of the polarization-preserving ambient magnetic field magnitude, will be used to characterize indirectly the loss rate associated with spin evolution in the trap, sufficient for completing measurement of the neutron lifetime to an accuracy of one second. Measurements in a dedicated test cell will provide information necessary to assess directly the effect of spin evolution in a very high-precision (well below 0.1%) magnetic trap measurement of the free neutron lifetime.

por.por_cntn:
The Periodic Table of Elements is a well-known way of organizing atoms, the objects from which the familiar physical world is built. The Periodic Table is based on our understanding of the properties of these atoms, which derive from the fact that they are not individual objects, but are composed of separate particles: protons, neutrons, and electrons. It is perhaps less well known that the protons and neutrons making up an atom are not themselves individual objects. A long-term scientific goal is to produce a "Periodic Table" that contains only fundamental particles, i.e. objects that are indivisible. This "Periodic Table" is called the Standard Model (SM) and has been under development since the nineteenth century. Just as the structure underlying the Periodic Table provides predictive power, the SM also makes predictions, and these predictions have been exhaustively and comprehensively tested. Despite the fact that these tests have time and again confirmed the SM, astronomical observations clearly demonstrate large-scale features of the universe, such as the existence of dark matter and a lack of antimatter, that the SM does not explain. The simplest reason for this situation is that there are undiscovered particles.

The conventional way to look for new particles is using particle colliders, where the hope is to produce and detect new particles by colliding known particles together with high energy. The collision technique is limited, however, by the maximum amount of energy that can be imparted to the colliding particles; for a fixed maximum energy, it is possible for there to be particles which simply cannot be created. The fact that no new particles have been discovered since 2012, despite ongoing collider experiments, suggests that none of the missing particles may be discoverable in this way. The overarching scientific impact of this project was its contribution to a search for new particles using a different approach. Rather than attempt to directly produce new particles, a system whose properties can be predicted using the SM is selected and measured with high precision. Because the SM, like the Periodic Table, is based on recurring patterns (symmetries), a disagreement between theoretical predictions and actual observations provides evidence for the existence of a new particle. Several such observed disagreements can be enough to define the properties and behavior of the new particle. This approach trades high energy for high precision and so is limited only by the precision with which theoretical calculations and experimental measurements can be conducted.

The system of study for this project was the neutron which, when separated from the nucleus of an atom, transforms (decays) into a proton, an electron, and one of the other known particles of the SM called an anti-neutrino. The quantity being measured was how long it takes, on average, for an isolated neutron to decay. This physical value has long been targeted by a number of experimental groups utilizing the high-precision paradigm because SM calculations of this process are reasonably precise. Nevertheless, there are significant technical challenges involved in measuring this neutron lifetime with a precision better than 0.1% of its value, with the ultimate goal being a measurement ten times more precise. The technique that has so far demonstrated the greatest precision involves confining very low energy "ultracold" neutrons (UCN) using a combination of magnetic fields and gravity. Using this method and the UCN source at Los Alamos National Lab, the UCN𝜏 collaboration carried out the most precise measurement of the neutron lifetime ever achieved. While the result has not demonstrated a definitive disagreement with the SM, it has established the importance of the neutron system in the search for new particles and has demonstrated a path forward to further improvements in precision for the neutron lifetime. This project contributed directly to the measurement while helping recruit and train a next generation of STEM professionals by creating a program at Tennessee Technological University in which early undergraduates from across the STEM disciplines, as well as high school students, could engage in authentic research, develop technical skills not traditionally taught in the classroom, gain experience communicating their work to a wide range of audiences, and discover that science at its best and most exciting is a social and collaborative activity. In addition to supporting and training these students as they helped the UCN𝜏 collaboration develop a neutron lifetime experiment and collect and analyze data from the measurement, this project focused on a demonstration that while confined within a "magneto-gravitational" trap, evolution of a neutron's quantum state would not create a significant systematic effect for the experiment. This work was accomplished using a variety of technical modalities of individual interest to the student project participants and included development of several novel tools: an autonomous magnetic mapper, a telescopic camera-based position-sensitive UCN detector, simulation and real-time 3d visualization code, and an optical quantum magnetometer.
